# Draft:Logistics of the 1948 Democratic, Republican, and Progressive National Conventions

Site selection
Philadelphia offered $200,000 per convention and rent-free use of the convention hall. https://www.newspapers.com/image/952800216
One of the main motivations for both major parties selecting Philadelphia was that the city was hooked up to a coaxial cable, allowing for live television broadcasts of the conventions to be carried on stations across several East Coast markets.
Television broadcasting
One of the main motivations for both major parties selecting Philadelphia was that the city was hooked up to the coaxial cable running between Washington, D.C. and New York City, giving the ability for two of the three then-young television networks, NBC and CBS, to telecast for the first time live gavel-to-gavel coverage to stations across several East Coast markets . Only a few minutes of kinescope film have survived of these historic, live television broadcasts. The coaxial cables cables allowed the television networks to broadcast live coverage to as many as 10 million viewers living on the East Coast.
The television networks agreed that they would use a pool feed for fixed-position footage. The networks installed five fixed-position cameras and shared a single feed director. In addition, networks had their floor correspondents travel with early TV mobile cameras, using early-model mobile setups that required correspondents to wear heavy equipment backpacks.
CBS Radio correspondent Edward R. Murrow successfully lobbied his employer to allow him to take part in the coverage of the CBS television network, and he was assigned a floor correspondent for the conventions.
Television broadcasting would be expanded upon during the 1952 Democratic and Republican conventions, which received nationwide live television broadcasts.
Preparation of Convention Hall
Ahead of the convention,
The convention took place amid a three-month heatwave impacting Philadelphia. The arena lacked air conditioning, and the heat generated by television lights inside of it only worsened attendees' discomfort. The heatwave was strong during the Republican convention, and only worsened by the time of the Democratic convention.
Other significant venues
The Progressives held the final evening of their convention (featuring acceptance speeches) at Shibe Park allowing a crowd of 32,000 to spectate Wallace's acceptance speech.
Hotels and other overnight accommodations
Philadelphia and its region lacked enough hotel rooms to adequately accommodate  the demand generated by the conventions.
Hotels in the
The Progressive convention's attendance was dominated not by experienced members of the political class, but by nascent political activists. Some in attendance camped in tents in a temporary tent city that popped-up in the convention center's parking lot during the Progressive convention.
Transportation
Some West Coast Republicans complained of the travel expenses required for them to attend a convention held on the East Coast. https://www.newspapers.com/image/564492249
Some of the political activists that attended the Progressive convention (which was, unlike the major party conventions, dominated by nascent activists than the experienced political class) traveled to Philadelphia by hitchhiking.
Funding
As it had pledged to, Philadelphia locally provided a total of $400,000 to fund the conventions, with each party receiving $200,000. By holding conventions in the same city, both parties saved money on preparations. They had done the same in the previous election, when they both met in Chicago.
